moe_section_title: Scope of Work, Capability Management, Changes Notification, MOE Amendment and Supplier/Component Control
summary: Section describes how the organisation ensures maintenance capability and readiness versus scope of work, defines the organisation’s scope of work (aircraft, components, line and workshop maintenance), explains how temporary lack of capability is handled, sets out procedures for notifying the NAA of organisational changes and for MOE amendment and distribution, and briefly describes supplier selection and incoming parts inspection and approval.

findings.requirement_excerpt: a specification of the scope of work of the organisation that is relevant to the terms of approval as required by point 145.A.20;
findings.reasoning: The MOE text provides a narrative description of the organisation’s scope of work (aircraft and equipment maintenance, A1/A2, C14 landing gear, line/workshop/equipment maintenance, reference to a separate Component Capability List). However, the description is fragmented, not clearly structured as a formal ‘terms of approval’ specification, and some key elements (exact aircraft types, ratings, locations, limitations) are only vaguely referenced or delegated to other sections without clear cross‑reference. This only partially fulfils the requirement for a clear specification of scope of work relevant to the approval.
findings.recommended_fix: Introduce a clearly structured subsection titled e.g. “2.x Scope of Work / Terms of Approval (145.A.70(a)(9))” that: (1) explicitly lists the organisation’s ratings and limitations in the same structure as the approval certificate (e.g. A1 Aeroplanes above 5700 kg – [list types]; A2 Aeroplanes 5700 kg and below – [list types]; C14 Landing Gear – [list types/part numbers]); (2) clearly references the Component Capability List as a controlled MOE attachment, including its document identifier and revision control; (3) clearly states any line maintenance limitations (e.g. ‘Line maintenance is limited to the tasks listed in Appendix X and within AMC 145.A.10 point 1, at locations listed in section 1.8.4’). Replace the current long paragraph starting with “Organization work scope The maintenance organization can perform maintenance…” with a concise, tabulated scope of work aligned with the approval certificate.

findings.requirement_id: 145.A.70(a) general – consistency and simplified English, page 420
findings.requirement_excerpt: Ensuring consistency in the design of procedures and the use of terminology, abbreviations, references, etc. … For documents produced in the English language, using ‘simplified English’.
findings.reasoning: The MOE text is written in very poor, partly machine‑translated English with many grammatical errors, broken sentences and unclear terminology (e.g. “capabilities temporary lack of identified and are taken into account work orders in approval”, “Provided something like that paragraph influence maintenance readiness, so technical manager does they measures”). This makes several procedures difficult to understand and does not meet the expectation of consistent terminology or simplified English for an English‑language MOE.
findings.recommended_fix:
Rewrite this section in clear, grammatically correct, simplified English and standardise terminology. For example: 
- Replace “capabilities temporary lack of identified and are taken into account work orders in approval” with “Any temporary lack of capability is identified and considered before accepting or approving a work order.”
- Replace “Provided something like that paragraph influence maintenance readiness, so technical manager does they measures, which the required readiness is achieved” with “If any of the above changes affect maintenance capability, the Technical Director shall take the necessary actions to restore the required capability before further work is accepted.”
Ensure consistent use of defined terms such as ‘maintenance capability’, ‘scope of work’, ‘Technical Director’, ‘NAA’, ‘work order’, and cross‑references to other MOE sections. Have the entire section reviewed by a fluent English speaker familiar with Part‑145 terminology.

findings.requirement_excerpt: The Part-145 organisation should take into account these elements to ensure that a clear contract or work order has been concluded before providing maintenance services.
findings.reasoning: The MOE text mentions that maintenance readiness of machines that are occasionally serviced is activated at the latest when the work order is approved, and that temporary lack of capability is taken into account in work order approval. This shows some linkage between capability and work order acceptance. However, it does not describe how the organisation ensures that a clear contract or work order exists with defined scope, responsibilities, and applicable maintenance data before starting work, nor does it reference the elements of a maintenance contract as suggested by the GM.
findings.recommended_fix: Add a short, explicit procedure for work order/contract acceptance, e.g.: “Before any maintenance is started, the Technical Director or nominated person shall ensure that a written contract or work order is in place with the customer. The contract/work order shall clearly define: (a) aircraft/ component identification; (b) requested work and applicable maintenance data; (c) responsibilities for continuing airworthiness and records; (d) any limitations or special conditions. The organisation shall verify that it has the necessary capability (personnel, tools, data, facilities) before accepting the work order. This verification and acceptance shall be recorded on form XX or in system YY.”

findings.requirement_excerpt: The following changes to the organisation shall require prior approval by the competent authority… All changes not requiring prior approval shall be managed and notified to the competent authority as set out in a procedure which is approved by the competent authority…
findings.reasoning: The MOE includes a ‘CHANGES NOTIFICATION’ subsection describing when the organisation informs the NAA (changes of name, locations, responsible manager/persons, quality manager, premises, equipment, tools, materials, methods, scope of work or certifying staff that may affect the operating permit). It also states that changes are discussed with the NAA before implementation where possible, and that EASA Form 2 and Form 4 are used. However, it does not clearly distinguish which changes require prior approval under 145.A.85(a) versus those that are managed under the ‘changes not requiring prior approval’ procedure in 145.A.85(c). The text also suggests that even indirectly approved MOE changes are only implemented after NAA confirmation of receipt, which is not clearly aligned with the concept of an internally approved procedure for non‑prior‑approval changes. The procedure is therefore only partially aligned with 145.A.85.
findings.recommended_fix: Revise the ‘CHANGES NOTIFICATION’ and ‘ORGANIZATION MANUAL AMENDMENT PROCEDURE’ subsections to: (1) explicitly list the changes that require prior approval in accordance with 145.A.85(a) (certificate/terms of approval, nominated persons, reporting lines, procedure for non‑prior‑approval changes, additional locations) and state that these changes will not be implemented until formal approval is received from the NAA; (2) define a separate, NAA‑approved procedure for changes not requiring prior approval under 145.A.85(c), including how they are internally approved (e.g. by Technical Director) and how/when they are notified to the NAA; (3) clarify that MOE changes within the scope of the indirect approval procedure may be implemented in accordance with the NAA‑approved indirect approval agreement, without waiting for explicit NAA confirmation of receipt, if that is consistent with the authority’s policy. Use clear headings such as ‘2.x Changes Requiring Prior Approval (145.A.85(a))’ and ‘2.y Changes Not Requiring Prior Approval (145.A.85(c))’ and cross‑reference the MOE amendment procedure.

findings.requirement_excerpt: The organisation shall establish and maintain a maintenance organisation exposition (MOE)…
findings.reasoning: The MOE describes an amendment procedure: page headers with revision level and date, no handwritten or temporary changes, change marking with vertical lines, use of a change list, electronic submission to NAA, distribution list, and archiving of old versions. It also describes an ‘indirect approval’ method for certain minor changes. This shows a structured control of the MOE. However, the description is somewhat confusing, mixing direct and indirect approval, and does not clearly state that the MOE must always reflect the organisation’s current structure and procedures. Some responsibilities (e.g. for ensuring all holders update their copies) are described but not very clearly. Overall, the control system is present but not clearly and simply described.
findings.recommended_fix: Clarify and streamline the MOE amendment procedure. For example: (1) Start with a clear policy statement: “The MOE shall at all times reflect the current organisation, facilities, personnel and procedures.” (2) Separate the process into ‘a) Changes requiring NAA approval’ and ‘b) Changes eligible for indirect approval’, describing for each who drafts, who approves internally, what is sent to NAA, and when the change may be implemented. (3) Clearly describe the distribution process: how personnel are informed, how electronic copies are updated, and how obsolete copies are withdrawn. (4) Use simple, unambiguous language and remove redundant or contradictory sentences (e.g. about when changes can be implemented).

findings.requirement_id: AMC1 145.A.42(a)(i) Components – EASA Form 1 or equivalent, page 386
findings.requirement_excerpt: A document equivalent to an EASA Form 1 may be: … a release document issued under the terms of a bilateral agreement … a JAA Form One … a ‘declaration of maintenance accomplished’…
findings.reasoning: The MOE describes a receiving inspection for incoming parts, devices and materials, including checking that required airworthiness documents are present and that goods and documents match. It also states that if airworthiness documents are incomplete, the goods are suspended or returned. However, it does not specify which documents are acceptable (EASA Form 1 or equivalent) nor does it reference the types of equivalent documents listed in AMC1 145.A.42(a)(i). Without this, staff may not have clear guidance on what constitutes acceptable release documentation.
findings.recommended_fix: Expand the incoming goods procedure to explicitly define acceptable airworthiness documentation, e.g.: “For components subject to Part‑145, the following documents are acceptable: (a) EASA Form 1; (b) documents equivalent to an EASA Form 1 in accordance with AMC1 145.A.42(a)(i), such as release documents issued under EU bilateral agreements, JAA Form One issued under specified conditions, or a ‘declaration of maintenance accomplished’ as per M.A.502(e)/ML.A.502(c), as applicable. The storekeeper or certifying staff shall verify that the document is valid, correctly completed, and applicable to the component. Components without an EASA Form 1 or acceptable equivalent shall not be installed and shall be quarantined until resolved.”

findings.requirement_excerpt: The organisation should ensure the proper identification of any unserviceable components. The unserviceable status of the component should be clearly declared on a tag together with the component identification data and any information that is useful to define actions that are necessary to be taken.
findings.reasoning: The provided MOE text for parts and materials inspection covers incoming goods, acceptance, and actions when goods are defective or documents incomplete (suspension, return, destruction). It does not clearly describe how unserviceable components are identified, tagged, segregated, and controlled within the organisation’s stores or during maintenance, as required by AMC1 145.A.42(a)(ii). This may be covered elsewhere in the MOE, but it is not evident in the excerpt.
findings.recommended_fix: Add a dedicated subsection on ‘Unserviceable Components’ aligned with AMC1 145.A.42(a)(ii), e.g.: “Any component identified as unserviceable (due to defects, life limit expiry, missing data, AD non‑compliance, etc.) shall be: (a) clearly tagged as ‘UNSERVICEABLE’ with component identification, reason for unserviceability, and relevant history (times/cycles, preservation status, defect description, accident/incident involvement); (b) recorded in the inventory system as unserviceable; (c) stored in a segregated, clearly marked quarantine area to prevent inadvertent installation; and (d) either sent for maintenance to an approved organisation or scrapped in accordance with procedure XX. The tag shall be attached in a way that prevents unintentional separation.”

findings.requirement_id: GM1 M.A.501(a)(1) / GM1 145.A.42(a)(i) – components not needing EASA Form 1, pages 95 & 386
findings.requirement_excerpt: Point 21.A.307(b)… specify new components that do not need an EASA Form 1 or equivalent to be eligible for installation…
findings.reasoning: The MOE does not address the specific case of new components that may be installed without an EASA Form 1 under Part‑21 provisions (e.g. certain standard parts). It only states that required airworthiness documents must be present, without distinguishing these exceptions. While not strictly mandatory to restate GM text, the absence of any guidance may lead to inconsistent practice.
findings.recommended_fix: Optionally clarify in the incoming goods procedure that certain new components may be eligible for installation without an EASA Form 1 in accordance with Part‑21 (21.A.307/21L.A.193), and that in such cases the accompanying documentation must meet the conditions specified in those rules. For example: “Where Part‑21 permits installation of new components without an EASA Form 1 (e.g. certain standard parts), the storekeeper shall verify that the component is accompanied by documentation meeting the conditions of 21.A.307(c)/21L.A.193(c) (e.g. manufacturer’s certificate of conformity) and that the component is clearly identifiable and traceable.”

findings.requirement_id: Supplier and subcontractor control – AMC/GM to 145.A.42 & 145.A.75/145.A.205 (page 429 excerpt 4.4–4.7)
findings.requirement_excerpt: The subcontractor control procedure will need to address the relevant management system key processes such as safety risk management and compliance monitoring… The contract between the Part-145 organisation and the subcontractor should contain a provision to ensure that access to the subcontractor is granted to any person authorised by the authorities…
findings.reasoning: The MOE states that the organisation uses EASA‑approved organisations or manufacturers as suppliers, may use standard suppliers, maintains a supplier list, monitors reliability and quality through deliveries, and changes suppliers if recurring problems occur. It also states that the maintenance organisation does not use subcontractors. This provides a basic supplier control concept but does not describe a formal supplier evaluation/approval process, criteria, periodic review, or how safety risk management and compliance monitoring interact with supplier control. For subcontractors, stating ‘no subcontractors’ is acceptable if true, but the MOE should still define what would be considered a subcontractor and how such arrangements would be controlled if introduced.
findings.recommended_fix: Enhance the supplier control section by: (1) defining a formal process for supplier evaluation and approval (initial assessment, criteria such as approvals, quality history, capability, and how they are added to the approved supplier list); (2) describing periodic review of suppliers (e.g. annual review of performance, non‑conformities, on‑site audits where appropriate); (3) linking supplier control to the compliance monitoring function (e.g. “The compliance monitoring function reviews supplier performance and audits the supplier control process annually.”). Add a short statement on subcontractors: “The organisation currently does not use subcontractors as defined in Part‑145. If subcontracted maintenance is introduced, it shall be controlled in accordance with a dedicated subcontractor control procedure meeting the requirements of 145.A.75 and related AMC/GM, including contractual access for the NAA and audit/oversight provisions.”
